"Look around you. This horrible bunch of psychopaths are all begging to join up with me, but unfortunately for them, I only take the best. And today, best means whoever can kill you. Come on out lads. It's initiation time."

[i]Batman: Arkham City[/i] is an action-adventure game developed by Rocksteady Studios and published by Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment.

[b]Story[/b]
I suggest playing through Arkham Asylum first, as events from that game are used as a setup to setting of this one.

Arkham City takes place 18 months after Arkham Asylum events. Taking credit for stopping Joker's siege, director Sharp becomes a Mayor of Gotham City. Declaring Asylum no longer suitable, he creates immense prison enclosure known as Arkham City inside Gotham's slums, taken care of by mysterious Hugo Strange while monitored by private military firm TYGER Security. Our protagonist, Bruce Wayne, opposes that idea and ends up in a titular prison himself. Here as Batman he wants to find out more about mysterious Protocol 10 and real intentions behind the prison.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
If you played Arkham Asylum, you already know what to expect as City builds up upon gameplay from previous game, providing third person open world venture where you will investigate, explore, stealth and brawl through the prison as our favourite Caped Crusader, searching for truth (and few faces to soak your fists in).
First thing you will experience is the main dish of the game- combat. Punch, kick, smack thugs before they smack you to avoid a dreadful fate of watching villians laugh in your face as you lose and reload a checkpoint. Counter or dodge incoming attacks, chain up combinations to gain speed and power, utilize plenty of gadgets to surprise your opponents. Game provides improved version of the "Freeflow" combat system, meaning you can now perform more moves, such as option to counter multiple attacks at once or being able to chain combinations for long enough to unleash deadly special attacks. Enemies can be armed with different armor and weapons, forcing you to adjust your moves accordingly.

Sometimes you get a chance to resolve encounters silently. Similar scenario as with first game, utilize vantage points, environment, detective vision and your gadgets to eliminate enemies without them noticing you. Watch as fear strikes their minds and heartpulse keeps rising with each performed takedown on their buddies, but just like in combat, thugs are a bit more Bat-proof this time so they come with more firearms, jammers and extra tools that will make your life harder, as tides can quickly shift back and forth. Know when to strike and when to wait for opportunity, or just create your own!

Arkham City opens up the area, providing way more space to explore. Glide, grapple and sprint around looking for collectibles that expand the narrative and lore, side activities, or just seek out local thugs waiting for a fight! (Or to be knocked out silently by a sneaky Bat.) Fans favourite Riddler returns with his trophies and riddles, while other villians make an appearance in side quests spread all over the prison, unlockable as you progress through the story. Same applies to gadgets, so you might have to wait a bit to obtain a tool or two before you can enter certain buildings or collect specific trophies. No pressure, you can always return to every area you visited.

Combat and exploration grant you experience points, earn enough to level Batman up and unlock new skills, moves, or improve gadgets.

[b]Playtime, other modes[/b]
It took me roughly 13 hours to complete everything in Arkham City. After beating the story you unlock New Game Plus where you can utilize everything you have unlocked with increased overall difficulty to balance it out. Additionally there is "Riddler's Revenge" mode, where you tackle on different challenge maps and campaigns for medals! Fair to say you can spend a bit more time in City than you might think at first glance, if interested. Especially as this version comes with extra DLC, Catwoman content, and extra characters in RR mode.

[b]Impressions[/b]
Out of the gate I will go out with a very bold claim- Arkham City is probably the best sequel I ever had a pleasure to play. A textbook definition of how they should be made. It's not a revolution, but an evolution. If you played Asylum you feel right at home almost instantly as game keeps same great controls and fantastic core gameplay allowing you to quickly get into action, increasing and opening up the location where game takes place, addition of side quests and expanded lore make it feel like an entirely new experience. Already great combat is now reaching superb levels, it's smooth, it's intuitive, with very tight controls and top notch precision when it comes to inputs as if game knows which thug you want to hit before you even do. Some annoying moments from Asylum where Batman in the middle of combination would decide to punch ghosts are gone, combined with new moves and gadgets it practically makes you beg for as many enemies on screen as possible to go wild.

But game knows when to slow down, when to give you a stealth section to showcase pretty solid enemy AI, allowing you to fully lean into Batman's strategic side with various gadgets, careful planning and utilization of environment to his advantage. Quite frankly it's a shame that because game is no longer as linear as first title, plus complete change of area where game takes place so it's almost impossible to just give you a stealth section in the middle of the city, it doesn't actually have that many of those section. But when you get them, it's an absolute treat to play.

Asylum no doubt had it's own unique atmosphere, but City is no slouch in that department either. Prison filled with crime in the middle of gang wars, with secrets on top of secrets, the mash of destroyed slums with iconic locations, freedom you get to explore it and encounter many more and lesser known villians across short yet satisfying side quests, it hits right. Fortunately game never feels too long, it doesn't drag on, even if you decide to dive into the madness that is collecting those forsaken trophies.
Fantastic audiovisual side, strong art direction, top of the game performance from voice actors and animators, game even today looks fairly impressive. Forgot to even mention expanded extra side mode of the game in which you can spend plenty hours, if running around Arkham City gets boring for you.

If there something...mixed, I can say about this game, it would probably be about the story. In my book the main villian in this one was a bit..disappointing? Especially as he was pretty much a "main face" when it came to promoting the game. I expected a better conclusion of certain arcs and felt like it could have focus on just one story, instead of jumping around and trying to have two main storylines branching out and at least for me, that never really worked. So yeah, story is enjoyable but I would like it to go into a different direction.

Nonetheless, Arkham City is simply superb. Easy recommendation. Combat feels great, explorating feels enjoyable, still holds up visually and it's a treat for fans of DC/Batman.

[b]Final words and conclusion[/b]
Said it before, gonna say it again, GOTY Edition comes with everything released so you get all the fun stuff- alternative costumes, post-main game DLC and extra characters- in one pack!

Batman: Arkham City improves pretty much everything from first game while still focusing on core strenghts- fantastic combat, great audiovisuals and intriguing exploration. Buy it, play it, enjoy it.

Feel free to check out [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/31947302/] my curator page [/url] for more reviews!

Batman: Arkham City is the extremely popular sequel to Batman: Arkham Asylum and for good. This game takes everything that was great about the first entry in the series and expands on it, and then some. 

The concept for Batman: Arkham City is a good simple one. A portion of Gotham city has been abandoned after a large flood. This led to it being constructed into a large open prison for the area's worst. The catch being Hugo Strange is in control and uses the prison city as the way of silencing his political opponents. This is where you find Bruce Wayne arrested at the start of the game and placed in prison. He naturally breaks free, acquires some Bat equipment and does what he does best. 

The game features a lot of returning characters like the Joker, Riddler, Bane etc. There's also some great new additions like Mr Freeze. All of the characters (including Batman) are all very well represented with excellent script writing and voice acting. A far cry from what we get with more recent games. 

The game play generally works the same. The combat is still rhythmic based. Basically, pushing attack in a slow pulse rhythm will cause the Bat to fly across the screen, hurting his foes whilst the combo rises. As you progress, you get more equipment and more moves to add to the combo. It ends up being some of the coolest game play in the entire Batman franchise. There's also the stealth, which is still really fun but isn't quite as focused here as it was in the first game. 

The biggest difference this game has to its predecessor is the fact it's open world. Not just a large hub, but full on open world. Where the first game felt like an episode of the Animated Series, this game covers a large city area and feels a lot more grand in scope. It's gigantic and a lot more open by comparison. 

Unfortunately, there's no fast travel. But there is a means to move around. You've just got to complete the little side quest to do it. There's also no lack of things to do. There's a number of really good story based side missions and plenty of Riddler trophies/puzzles to solve. These are all of varying difficulty but something I have always enjoyed doing. It's got a great living breathing world that changes depending on which story point you're at it. 

Personally speaking, I actually prefer the first game. The more focus hub and the linear story is more to my cup of tea. But whenever I revisit that game, I always come back and replay Arkham City. For good reason. This is an excellent game. Everything about it oozes high quality and it has aged really well. 

I just played through it on my Steam Deck. I had the graphics settings maxed out and I got through it without a single problem. It was quite smooth the entire time. I finished every main, side and Riddler quest. I had a great time and felt I should share that, as the Deck's popularity is sky rocketing. 

This game goes on sale quite regularly and I couldn't recommend it more. The entire series is very good and well worth the time.

After finishing Arkham Asylum in 2025, I played this right away, and it's the ideal illustration of how a sequel should be done. It takes everything that made the first game special and expands it without losing focus.

The Open World: It's amazing to glide over Arkham City's streets after navigating the cramped hallways of Asylum. There is no problem with traversal.
The Villains: There are a ton of rogues in this gallery. In the history of video games, the boss battle with Mr. Freeze remains one of the best-designed interactions.
The Story: A more intricate and dark plot that keeps you interested right up until the very end. I was stunned by how it ended.

If Asylum is the foundation, City is the skyscraper. An absolute masterpiece that is mandatory playing in 2025.

A good sequel to Asylum, Arkham City features much of the same general gameplay and combat styles, and much of the same main characters, with some valuable additions and variations on enemies. Levels can often feel unintuitive and restrictive, but it's a good enough play, especially if you like the IP.

Playtime: 14.3 hours (PC, controller, Steam Deck)

[b]Overall:  8/10[/b]

[u]Narrative: 8/10[/u] - Arkham City follows the aftermath of the fall of the expansive penitentiary and has Batman attempting to foil Joker's and Harley's destructive plans. As with Asylum and fitting with the theme of Batman in general, the story is simple, but silly, isolated and effective, and has a slightly more entertaining and engaging story than Asylum. The fast-paced narrative doesn't necessarily touch on anything deep but fits perfectly in the world of Batman and never felt stale. Harley Quinn's Revenge was a thematic, valuable addition to the story. With the main story, there doesn't seem to be an appropriate narrative resolution with regard to the scale of chaos in Arkham City, which made it feel a bit disjointed toward the end.

[u]Visuals: 9.5/10[/u] - An entirely new open world was crafted for this game and it looks great, even by today's standards. It's very well-built and looks great from almost anywhere, looking in any direction, especially with the inclusion of the background/sky box assets, which serve to make the already-large open world feel even larger. Batman has a very unique art style and it's executed quite well in this game (as in Asylum). The lighting effects and use of color in Arkham City are both done well and make the world feel almost cartoon-oriented, to the benefit of the game. Although the entirety of the open world is basically the same place (Arkham City), there is enough visual variation to make each part of the map feel distinct, and for indoor areas to not feel repetitive. Character models look great.

[u]Audio: 9/10[/u] - Rocksteady upped their game on the music/score since Asylum. The score is fantastic and never got repetitive. The voice acting, like the first game, is great and fits the style of the subject content. Combat sound effects are done well and also in a cartoon-ish sort-of way. Spatial audio was a bit lacking but nothing audio-related got repetitive in this game.

[u]Gameplay: 7/10[/u] - The gameplay in Arkham City is very similar to that of Asylum, sending you all over the open world to attempt to foil Joker's and Harley's plans, using numerous gadgets along the way to access different areas. Combat is much the same as in Asylum, with some minor changes and additions. The combat simple but fluid and fun and the player can be as creative as they want to with the gadgets during combat. Combat, character movement, and stealth are inventive enough, and game mechanics are introduced often enough, to not feel repetitive throughout the game. However, quite a few boss battles, and battles otherwise, are really just about figuring out what you're supposed to be doing whilst dying several times. What the player is supposed to do is often not self-explanatory and I often experienced the game telling what to do with text on screen. I think some better coordination with the level design team is in order to better align player expectations with what they are served in the game.

[u]Character Design: 8/10[/u] - Arkham City features Batman and Catwoman, and at times, Robin, as they try to stop Joker and Harley from destroying everything and killing everyone, with some special appearances by Clayface, Mr. Freeze, and others, which provides some nice variety through a playthrough without simply recycling enemies from the first game. The dialogue is simple but entertaining and effective and fits the theme of Batman well. I appreciated the opportunity to switch between characters/character models after beating the game. Characters are modeled well, look good in game, and fit nicely with the environment design. What they did with Joker throughout the game was cool and advanced the narrative in a meaningful way.

[u]Environment and Level Design: 6/10[/u] - One of my gripes from Asylum was that the interiors are easy to get lost in and it can be very difficult to find your way to an exit back to the open world. Indoor areas are maybe even a bit more confusing in City than in Asylum. I got lost several times and where the player is supposed to go is often unintuitive. In fact, a lot of what the player is supposed to be doing at any time is often unintuitive. The levels make it seem like there are many different ways to complete them, but they are often set up in a restrictive way which limits viable strategies immensely. There is also a lack of environmental storytelling as compared to Asylum. However, visually, all of the levels and world in general look great, and there is a great consistency and adherence to the art style.

[u]Personal Engagement: 8/10[/u]

[u]Personal Replay Value: 6.5/10[/u] - NG+

[u]Performance: 9/10[/u] - 2k144 on PC, no performance issues. Flawless performance on Steam Deck. Steam Cloud saves enabled. Minus one for the annoying title sequence on launch.

If you play it casually, the game wears its age well, great gameplay and a good story, a worthy edition to the "Golden Age" of game development; until you try to hundred percent it. At first, the challenges seem like they're going to be a breeze until you're on the hundredth challenge from the same 9 maps, for 4 unique characters each with their unique set of 3 repeating challenges.  

This game is the sunk cost fallacy in digital form. Some people on the spectrum will say completing all achievements is a badge of honor, but in reality, it's a sign, a wake up call, that you have no one in your life who loves you enough to tell you to stop. Even after getting my last achievement there was no sense of accomplishment just the weight of knowing what I had just done. And the realization that, like the journey itself, I meant nothing. When I'm in hell, hundred percenting this game as Catwoman will be how I'm tortured.

All in all a great game, 8/10, would not play again.

A sequel is the most dangerous addition to story telling. Sequels are hard because the expectations are sky high after the success of the first/original title in a series. If it succeeds then it opens up a whole new world of possibilities, but if it fails or disappoints, not only does it ruin/end the future of the series but it also ruins the experience of the original as you know the end is not as great as the beginning. After the huge success of Arkham Asylum, expectations were over the top for this one. Not only did it meet those expectations but it ended up exceeding them in very significant ways. Combat was improved, stealth was improved, story was even better than the first, bigger open world than Asylum, amazing voice acting as always. As I said in my review of the first game, the graphics still hold up almost 15 years later. Definitely would recommend. Play it !!!!!

Replayed it in 2025 for the first time in 10 years. I owned this on Xbox 360 before I ever got it on Steam - but this version was free from WB as I had bought Arkham Knight and it released with a lot of bugs - so WB gave early purchases the whole Arkham collection. 

Still a great game looks pretty good despite its age. The map is pretty small but dense, there are lots of interiors and the city always feels alive as enemies always swarm the streets and gain new dialogue as you progress the story. There are 440 Riddler trophies/challenges/riddles in total to get through, which isn't actually too hard and can be done without using a guide in a few days - but they are fun to collect. It's not just a matter of going to markers and picking them up, but most require some wit, a puzzle and a bit of finesse to unlock. 

The puzzles are great and exactly how they should be in a game, you unlock progressively an assortment of gadgets that allow you to react to your environment, which can help in combat, or access new areas in places you have visited prior. (As opposed to games obsessed with skill trees, where you just hit quantitative checklists where you just boost stats until the game is too easy). There are perks to unlock here too, but they hit a nice balance to gives you some new abilities without feeling overpowered, because as you progress enemies too get new gear and as battles mix up the types of enemies you face, you need to react precisely or lose your flow. This is gaming done right, too many devs do not understand it and think that difficulty is simple integer modification: give them more health and damage, give you less of both, all perks just change integers - lazy, un-innovative development.

 The controls feel tight and you can easily manoeuvre Batman around the city, as well as in stealth and melee combat. 
The game should pack at least 10 hours if you just focus on the main mission, and over 25 if you go for all side quests and Riddler trophies (keep in mind Steam doesn't log hours played, it logs hours the game is running). Unlike many other generic titles, going for 100% is fun and addictive in this game, even in 2025, where I have abandoned so many others. By contrast I gave Spiderman 2018 a go, but had a lot of dislike for it as it leaned so much into genericness without interesting puzzles, bland combat, non reactive AI and a map that is huge but just has you doing simple pickups or wave fights. 

Overall I can recommend this game, Asylum and Knight - the Triology - then pretend Origins never existed.

It's tough to give this a binary "Recommended / Not Recommended" review here, but ultimately I think I have to give it a Thumbs Down. The continuation from Asylum was great. I enjoy the combat, even if some of the later brawls were just a ridiculous amount of enemies in single rooms. The rooms where you sneakily take down sentries one-by-one is fun, even if they copy/paste that formula repeatedly in the same rooms. The story is exactly what I would expect from a Batman game, and I enjoyed the inclusion of classic Batman characters throughout. I really liked the idea of the open-world map, and while I think Asylum's smaller map led to tighter segments, expanding that to a full "city" was a cool to see.

That being said, I think the city kinda collapsed under it's own weight. Movement was incredibly unfun. In a post-Insomnia Spider-Man world, it wasn't nearly as zippy enough, nor was it particularly dangerous to move between regions. It just felt like a slog. This was made worse by there being a large impenetrable wall in the middle of map, forcing you to go the long way around constantly throughout the game. It didn't take long to make this feel like a chore instead of an engaging part of the gameplay. It obviously wanted you to interact with the collectibles along the way, like the Riddler trophies, but so many of those require gadgets you get later, it feels bad to try and remember ALL of them to return to later. Once I decided I wasn't going to get them all, I didn't care to stop and explore the map.

This really was just made worse by the Catwoman DLC. Since I'm playing the GOTY version a decade after release, I didn't realize this was bonus content and just played her segments as part of the base experience. She shows up so infrequently, and her segments are so underbaked, it ultimately felt really bad to play her (especially since she had practically no upgrades by the end).

While I did find the story serviceable, I did think the ending was very underwhelming, especially since it cuts right to a Catwoman segment. I felt like I was missing a good ending or something due to how abruptly things resolve. I guess they're hinting at the third game in the trilogy, but it still felt like it's missing something.

I think at this point, you've made your mind up on whether you're playing this decade-old game in a lauded trilogy. It's definitely worth a shot if you want to experience the Arkham games. But I couldn't really see myself returning to this in the same way I might revisit Asylum in the future. Just too much busywork and not enough pay-off.

Batman: Arkham City is in my opinion incredibly over rated, just like Arkam Asylum. The reasons why I didn't like this game are the same as before, which I described in detail in the review of Asylum.

Briefly: It's not a bad game, it has a story, decent graphics (but it's always dark, because in the Batman world it's always night) and sound. But I don't like the combo based beat them up combat, that is clearly easier if you have a controller. It works fine when you have a few enemies around but when you are surrounded by 10 or 15 enemies each with their own attack mechanics to counter, it's just frustrating and leads to many reloads. Also the bosses battles are poor because each have only 1 formula or way to beat them. 

Another thing I don't like is the concept of unending "trophies" and riddles to find/solve all around the map. I don't understand why many gamers find that paradigm amusing. It's the same as in Assasin's Creed, except in those games you only have trophies to find (and not too many), but here you have also all kinds of riddles and trophies that are unlocked by platforming puzzles. 

Arkham City has an semi-open world, instead of being linear like Asylum, and you have main and side quests. But the side quests are very poor and not done well. They only give you some vague clues but basically you have to search the entire map for their locations. And each side quests has many spawning/trigger event locations. I only managed to solve 50% of side  quests. Who knows where the rest are, and some are bugged, they don't trigger. 
Mediocre.

Batman: Arkham City is in my opinion incredibly over rated, just like Arkam Asylum. The reasons why I didn't like this game are the same as before, which I described in detail in the review of Asylum.

Briefly: It's not a bad game, it has a story, decent graphics (but it's always dark, because in the Batman world it's always night) and sound. But I don't like the combo based beat them up combat, that is clearly easier if you have a controller. It works fine when you have a few enemies around but when you are surrounded by 10 or 15 enemies each with their own attack mechanics to counter, it's just frustrating and leads to many reloads. Also the bosses battles are poor because each have only 1 formula or way to beat them. 

Another thing I don't like is the concept of unending "trophies" and riddles to find/solve all around the map. I don't understand why many gamers find that paradigm amusing. It's the same as in Assasin's Creed, except in those games you only have trophies to find (and not too many), but here you have also all kinds of riddles and trophies that are unlocked by platforming puzzles. 

Arkham City has an semi-open world, instead of being linear like Asylum, and you have main and side quests. But the side quests are very poor and not done well. They only give you some vague clues but basically you have to search the entire map for their locations. And each side quests has many spawning/trigger event locations. I only managed to solve 50% of side  quests. Who knows where the rest are, and some are bugged, they don't trigger. 
Mediocre.
